traits.label: Richness
traits.detail: Preference for marbling and fat-driven mouthfeel.

traits.label: Bold Flavor
traits.detail: Preference for deep, beef-forward flavor intensity.

traits.label: Adventure
traits.detail: Comfort with less-common cuts and techniques.

questionRelevanceNotes.flavor: This sets flavor intensity. Lighter answers favor cleaner, easier cuts; bolder answers prioritize deeper beef flavor and char-friendly cuts.
questionRelevanceNotes.richness: This sets marbling (intermuscular fat) preference. More marbling typically improves flavor intensity, juiciness, and perceived tenderness.
questionRelevanceNotes.texture: This sets bite preference. Tender answers lift soft-bite cuts; firmer answers lift meaty, beef-forward muscles.
questionRelevanceNotes.method: This sets heat compatibility. We boost cuts that perform reliably with your cooking method.
questionRelevanceNotes.comfort: This sets complexity range. Higher comfort allows specialty cuts; lower comfort keeps recommendations familiar and easier to execute.
questionRelevanceNotes.cuisine: This sets dish context. Steakhouse favors premium plated cuts; American grill favors cookout/value-friendly cuts and handheld formats.
questionRelevanceNotes.specialty_cuts: This confirms how far to go beyond common cuts. High comfort widens the recommendation pool; low comfort narrows it.
questionRelevanceNotes.advanced_technique: This sets technical fit. We match cuts to the cooking control and prep depth you actually want to use.
questionRelevanceNotes.butcher_precision: This sets purchasing precision. Exact preferences favor spec-sensitive cuts; flexible preferences favor easier substitutions.
questionRelevanceNotes.guidance_level: This sets recommendation format. We tune for simple direction vs exploratory options based on your preference.
questionRelevanceNotes.doneness: This sets finish target. Cuts that hold quality at your preferred doneness are ranked higher.
questionRelevanceNotes.seasoning: This sets seasoning lane. Simple prep favors cleaner high-quality cuts; rub/sauce lanes favor cuts that carry stronger seasoning.
questionRelevanceNotes.portion: This sets service format. We shift between plated steaks, sliced board cuts, tacos/bowls, or handheld options.
questionRelevanceNotes.budget: This sets spend range. Premium answers keep higher-end cuts active; value answers prioritize price-performance options.
questionRelevanceNotes.priority: This sets scoring emphasis. Your priority drives the final tie-break between otherwise similar cuts.
questionRelevanceNotes.flexibility: This captures buying behavior at the meat case. We infer how wide backup options should be across Levels 1-4.
questionRelevanceNotes.bone: This sets bone profile. Bone-in preference elevates bone-in cuts; boneless preference filters toward boneless options.
questionRelevanceNotes.cook_window: This captures prep tolerance. We convert this into a practical cook window to sort fast-turn versus project cuts.
questionRelevanceNotes.smoke: This sets smoke intensity fit. Higher smoke preference boosts cuts that hold up under fire and longer cook paths.
questionRelevanceNotes.fat_cap: This sets fat-edge tolerance. Lean preferences reduce fat-forward cuts; higher tolerance increases them.
questionRelevanceNotes.chew: This sets chew profile. Lower chew favors tender cuts; higher chew allows firmer cuts with stronger beef character.
questionRelevanceNotes.meal_format: This sets your core steak lane. We infer service style (plated, sliced board, tacos/bowls, sandwich/bun) for level placement.
questionRelevanceNotes.leftovers: This sets next-day usability. Leftover-friendly answers boost cuts that reheat and repurpose cleanly.
questionRelevanceNotes.occasion: This sets occasion weighting. Weeknight answers favor practicality; special-event answers favor presentation.
questionRelevanceNotes.crust: This sets sear intensity. High-crust answers elevate cuts that can take aggressive surface heat.
questionRelevanceNotes.routine: This sets purchase cadence. Frequent buyers get consistency/value emphasis; occasional buyers can lean premium.
questionRelevanceNotes.pairing: This sets plate balance. Side choices help us avoid over- or under-rich combinations for the full meal.

cuts.name: Ribeye
cuts.tagline: High-marbling benchmark with broad consumer acceptance.
cuts.rationale: Ribeye is appropriate when the profile prioritizes marbling, savory persistence, and forgiving cookability.
imps: 112A - Beef Rib, Ribeye Roll, Lip-On, Boneless
1112C - Beef Rib, Ribeye Steak, Boneless

cooking.method: High-heat sear with optional controlled finishing
cooking.note: Rest 5-8 minutes before slicing.

cuts.name: Tomahawk Ribeye
cuts.tagline: Bone-in ribeye presentation with premium visual impact.
cuts.rationale: Tomahawk ribeye fits premium steakhouse intent when the user wants rich flavor, showpiece plating, and controlled high-heat execution.
imps: 1103 - Beef Rib, Rib Steak, Bone-In (Tomahawk/Frenched style reference)
11103A - Beef Rib Steak, Bone-In, Frenched (market reference)

cooking.method: Two-zone grill or reverse sear with indirect finish
cooking.note: Use indirect heat to finish evenly due to thickness and bone mass.

cuts.name: Ribeye Cap
cuts.tagline: Elite richness concentration with premium tenderness.
cuts.rationale: Ribeye cap performs best for users with maximal richness preference and low price sensitivity.
imps: 112D - Beef Rib, Ribeye Cap, Boneless
1112D - Beef Rib, Ribeye Cap Steak, Boneless

cooking.method: Rapid high-heat sear to preserve internal fat quality
cooking.note: Avoid prolonged finishing to prevent fat washout.

cuts.name: New York Strip
cuts.tagline: Structured steakhouse texture with high flavor clarity.
cuts.rationale: Strip loin is a strong fit for balanced users seeking flavor definition and moderate marbling.
imps: 180 - Beef Loin, Strip Loin, Boneless
1180 - Beef Loin, Strip Loin Steak, Boneless

cooking.method: Cast-iron or grill with two-zone finishing
cooking.note: Trim or score external fat edge to reduce flare-up risk.

cuts.name: Bone-In New York Strip
cuts.tagline: Classic strip character with bone-in presentation.
cuts.rationale: Bone-in strip aligns with traditionalist profiles wanting a defined steakhouse format and stronger plate identity.
imps: 1179 - Beef Loin, Strip Loin, Bone-In
1179A - Beef Loin, Strip Loin Steak, Bone-In

cooking.method: Sear direct heat then finish indirect
cooking.note: Account for slower thermal rise adjacent to bone.

cuts.name: Strip Filet
cuts.tagline: Less common strip derivative with tighter portion geometry.
cuts.rationale: This format fits precision-driven users who want strip flavor with refined portioning.
imps: 1180B - Beef Loin, Strip Loin Steak, Boneless, Center-Cut, Split

cooking.method: Controlled sear with close temperature tracking
cooking.note: Smaller muscle geometry can overcook quickly.

cuts.name: Filet Mignon
cuts.tagline: Maximum tenderness with lower fat intensity.
cuts.rationale: Tenderloin is indicated when tenderness and precision outrank maximal beef intensity.
imps: 190 - Beef Loin, Tenderloin, Side Muscle Off, Defatted
1190 - Beef Loin, Tenderloin Steak, Side Muscle Off, Defatted

cooking.method: Pan sear then oven finish
cooking.note: Low intramuscular fat demands strict temperature discipline.

cuts.name: Filet Medallions
cuts.tagline: Tenderloin medallion format for fast, refined portioned service.
cuts.rationale: Filet medallions are selected when tenderness, quick cook time, and portion control are prioritized over intense beef flavor.
imps: 1190M - Beef Loin, Tenderloin Medallions, Boneless (market reference)

cooking.method: Fast pan sear with careful carryover control
cooking.note: Because medallions are small, pull early and rest briefly.

cuts.name: Porterhouse
cuts.tagline: Dual-muscle premium format combining strip and tenderloin.
cuts.rationale: Porterhouse suits profiles that want high occasion value and dual-texture presentation.
imps: 1173 - Beef Loin, Porterhouse Steak, Bone-In

cooking.method: Two-zone grill or reverse sear
cooking.note: Manage doneness asymmetry between strip and tenderloin sections.

cuts.name: T-Bone
cuts.tagline: Classic bone-in composite steak with balanced character.
cuts.rationale: T-bone aligns with users who value tradition, visual impact, and mixed texture.
imps: 1174 - Beef Loin, T-Bone Steak, Bone-In

cooking.method: Direct/indirect hybrid grilling
cooking.note: Rotate regularly to moderate edge overcooking.

cuts.name: Top Sirloin
cuts.tagline: Reliable utility steak with strong cost efficiency.
cuts.rationale: Top sirloin supports value-aware profiles needing repeatable performance across cooking methods.
imps: 184 - Beef Loin, Top Sirloin Butt, Boneless
1184 - Beef Loin, Top Sirloin Butt Steak, Boneless

cooking.method: Direct grill or cast-iron sear
cooking.note: Dry-brine improves consistency and surface browning.

cuts.name: Baseball Sirloin
cuts.tagline: Thick center-cut sirloin with improved tenderness perception.
cuts.rationale: Baseball-cut top sirloin matches users wanting sirloin value with elevated plate format.
imps: 184F - Beef Loin, Top Sirloin Butt, Center-Cut, Cap Off, Boneless
1184F - Beef Loin, Top Sirloin Butt Steak, Center-Cut, Boneless

cooking.method: Sear then finish to target center
cooking.note: Thickness benefits from reverse sear workflow.

cuts.name: Picanha
cuts.tagline: Cap-driven richness with strong beef identity.
cuts.rationale: Coulotte fits exploratory diners who value fat-cap rendering and robust slicing service.
imps: 184D - Beef Loin, Top Sirloin Butt, Cap, Boneless
1184D - Beef Loin, Top Sirloin Cap Steak, Boneless

cooking.method: Skewer/grill or reverse sear whole then slice
cooking.note: Render cap gradually before final high-heat crusting.

cuts.name: Tri-Tip
cuts.tagline: High flavor throughput with excellent serving flexibility.
cuts.rationale: Tri-tip supports value-performance profiles and large-format sliced service.
imps: 185C - Beef Loin, Bottom Sirloin Butt, Tri-Tip, Boneless
1185C - Beef Loin, Bottom Sirloin Butt, Tri-Tip Steak, Boneless

cooking.method: Reverse sear or Santa Maria-style live fire
cooking.note: Slice across changing grain directions to maintain tenderness.

cuts.name: Bavette
cuts.tagline: Underutilized cut with high flavor density.
cuts.rationale: Sirloin flap is ideal for adventurous users prioritizing flavor intensity and value.
imps: 1185A - Beef Loin, Bottom Sirloin Butt, Flap Steak, Boneless

cooking.method: Very hot, fast sear with immediate slicing
cooking.note: Mandatory grain-aware slicing for tenderness optimization.

cuts.name: Ball Tip Steak
cuts.tagline: Lean sirloin derivative with solid value utility.
cuts.rationale: Ball tip matches efficient buyers seeking lower-fat steak format with acceptable chew.
imps: 1185B - Beef Loin, Bottom Sirloin Butt, Ball Tip Steak, Boneless

cooking.method: Quick sear or marinated grill
cooking.note: Benefits from resting and thin slicing.

cuts.name: Flat Iron
cuts.tagline: High tenderness-to-price ratio with strong flavor.
cuts.rationale: Flat iron is a high-performing recommendation for users balancing tenderness, flavor, and value.
imps: 114D - Beef Chuck, Shoulder Clod, Top Blade
1114D - Beef Chuck, Shoulder Clod, Top Blade Steak

cooking.method: Fast high-heat sear
cooking.note: Slice across the grain after brief resting.

cuts.name: Denver Steak
cuts.tagline: Chuck-derived secondary steak with rich flavor potential.
cuts.rationale: Denver is suitable for exploratory users who want substantial flavor and strong value alignment.
imps: 116G - Beef Chuck, Under Blade, Center Cut
1116G - Beef Chuck, Under Blade, Center Cut Steak

cooking.method: Cast-iron or grill over moderate-high heat
cooking.note: Do not overcook to preserve tenderness.

cuts.name: Chuck Eye Steak
cuts.tagline: Rib-like flavor characteristics at lower cost.
cuts.rationale: Chuck eye fits value-oriented profiles seeking rib-adjacent flavor expression.
imps: 116H - Beef Chuck, Chuck Eye Roll
1116H - Beef Chuck, Chuck Eye Roll Steak

cooking.method: High-heat sear with short carryover
cooking.note: Trim seam fat as needed for more uniform texture.

cuts.name: Hanger Steak
cuts.tagline: High-mineral, high-character steak for experienced users.
cuts.rationale: Hanger is best for adventurous diners who prioritize flavor complexity over maximal tenderness.
imps: 140 - Beef Loin, Hanging Tender
1140 - Beef Loin, Hanging Tender Steak

cooking.method: Very hot, short-duration sear
cooking.note: Remove membrane thoroughly before cooking.

cuts.name: Flank Steak
cuts.tagline: Lean cut with excellent slicing-service versatility.
cuts.rationale: Flank matches high-value, technique-competent users comfortable with post-cook slicing control.
imps: 193 - Beef Flank, Flank Steak

cooking.method: High-heat grill or broiler
cooking.note: Slice very thin against grain for best tenderness.

cuts.name: Outside Skirt Steak
cuts.tagline: Premium skirt expression with intense beef flavor.
cuts.rationale: Outside skirt suits users who prioritize maximal flavor character and are comfortable with aggressive heat.
imps: 1121E - Beef Plate, Outside Skirt Steak, Skinned

cooking.method: Hard sear over high radiant heat
cooking.note: Excellent for short marination and slicing service.

cuts.name: Boneless Short Rib
cuts.tagline: Rich cut suited to grill or braise programs.
cuts.rationale: Boneless short rib matches bold-flavor users and BBQ-oriented cooking styles with high flavor payoff.
imps: IMPS Series 100 - Beef Plate, Short Rib, Boneless (family reference)

cooking.method: Slow braise or controlled high-heat grill
cooking.temp: Braise to probe-tender or grill to 130-137F
cooking.note: Outstanding for BBQ and high-flavor applications.

cuts.name: All-Beef Uncured Angus Hot Dog
cuts.tagline: Angus beef cookout option for fast, casual service.
cuts.rationale: All-beef uncured Angus hot dog fits profiles prioritizing speed, familiarity, and value-forward cookout meals.
imps: All-beef uncured hot dog (processed beef item reference)

cooking.method: Direct grill or griddle, quick-turn cook
cooking.doneness: Heat through with light casing blister
cooking.note: Serve immediately after blistering for best snap and texture.

Rib: Use two-zone heat so you can sear first, then finish gently.
Pull slightly early and rest 5-8 minutes to keep rendered fat in the meat.
Salt 30-60 minutes ahead for stronger crust and better interior seasoning.
Flip every 45-60 seconds for more even edge-to-edge doneness.
Loin: Pat dry before searing to build browning quickly without steaming.
Use high heat for color, then moderate heat to finish without overcooking.
Rest on a rack so the crust stays crisp.
Slice against the grain, especially on larger loin cuts.
Sirloin: Cook to medium-rare or medium and slice thin across the grain.
A short marinade (30-120 minutes) can improve texture on leaner sirloin cuts.
Use a thermometer to avoid overshooting internal temperature.
For large pieces, reverse sear for better doneness control.
Chuck: Chuck cuts perform best with either fast high heat plus slicing, or low-and-slow.
If grilling, slice thin against the grain immediately after resting.
Marinades with salt, acid, and oil improve tenderness and flavor carry.
Avoid overcooking lean chuck steaks past medium unless braising.
Plate: Keep plate cuts hot and fast; they lose texture if held too long.
Trim excess surface fat to reduce flare-ups.
Rest briefly, then slice thin across the grain.
Strong seasoning and citrus finish pair well with plate cuts.
Flank: Cook flank hot and fast, then rest and slice very thin across the grain.
Marinate at least 30 minutes for deeper flavor and tenderness.
Do not overcook; medium-rare to medium preserves texture.
Cut on a bias for wider, more tender slices.
Round: Round cuts benefit from marinade and careful temperature control.
Keep doneness in the medium-rare to medium range for better tenderness.
Always slice thin against the grain before serving.
For thicker round cuts, use broil/grill then carryover rest.
Specialty: Use direct heat for quick browning, then finish based on thickness.
A thermometer and proper rest time prevent dry results.
Slice against the grain whenever muscle fibers are long.
Season early and keep post-cook slicing clean and deliberate.

ribeye: Render the fat cap first for 30-60 seconds before laying flat to sear.
Baste with butter in the final minute for deeper crust aroma.
tomahawk_ribeye: Start with indirect heat, then finish with a hard sear to prevent surface burn.
Rotate away from direct flame when bone side starts shielding one edge.
strip: Score the fat edge lightly to limit curling during sear.
Sear fat-edge side first to improve rendered bite.
filet_mignon: Wrap with butcher twine for more even shape and doneness.
High-heat sear first, then finish gently to avoid gray bands.
filet_medallions: Use a very hot pan and short cook windows on each side.
Rest briefly (2-4 minutes) so juices redistribute without carryover overshoot.
picanha: Slice with the grain into steaks before cooking, then slice across grain to serve.
Render fat cap thoroughly; that is where most of the flavor payoff sits.
tri_tip: Track grain direction before cooking; it shifts midway across the roast.
Slice in two sections so each piece is cut against its grain direction.
bavette: Cook bavette rare to medium-rare and always slice thin on bias.
Rest slightly longer (7-10 minutes) before slicing to reduce purge.
flat_iron: Cook hot and fast; it behaves best like a thin steakhouse cut.
Do not cook far past medium or texture turns dense.
hanger: Trim silverskin well; leave some fat for flavor.
Use aggressive sear and pull at medium-rare for best texture.
flank: Use a tight grain-direction slice pattern; thick slices eat chewy.
Finish with acid (lemon/lime/vinegar) right before serving.
outside_skirt: Outside skirt needs very little time; prioritize color over prolonged cook.
Cut into manageable lengths before cooking for better pan contact.
all_beef_uncured_hot_dog: Warm gently first, then blister over direct heat for snap without splitting.
Roll frequently to brown evenly on all sides.
Choose 100% Angus beef franks for fuller beef flavor and better bite.
Toast the bun and apply condiments after the dog is off heat.
